events.summary: Boulanger made a grand return to France, presumably ready to conquer the music world, on an unassuming day in February. One could imagine her strutting off the train with a suitcase full of compositions and a flair for drama.

In a humorous twist, when Gershwin, the famed composer, asked Boulanger for lessons, he got a witty response instead. After a brief chat, she declared she could teach him nothing, and he humorously took it as the highest form of compliment.

Amidst the chaos of riots, Boulanger rose like a phoenix (or maybe just a determined conductor) and made her Paris debut. She bravely tackled Mozart, Bach, and Françaix, proving that music could unite even during turmoil.

events.event: First woman to conduct London Philharmonic Orchestra
events.summary: Boulanger broke barriers by substituting for a famous pianist and commanding the London Philharmonic Orchestra, all while ensuring her dynamic levels didn't scare off any faint-hearted musicians.
With her passion for Monteverdi, Boulanger decided to record some madrigals, delighting many but raising eyebrows among purists who weren't quite ready for modern instruments playing old tunes.

events.event: Conducted complete concert of Royal Philharmonic Society
events.summary: Boulanger became the first woman to conduct a full concert of the Royal Philharmonic Society, showcasing her penchant for delicate dynamics and powerful expressions without ever cranking it up to eleven.

Boulanger began a whirlwind tour of America where she conducted several major orchestras and delivered over a hundred lectures, proving that she was not just a maestro but also a master of multitasking.

events.event: Moved to New York before WWII
events.summary: Just before chaos ensued, Boulanger made a tactical move across the ocean to New York, bringing her unique blend of charm and musical genius to the bustling American scene, escaping the storm brewing in Europe.

Taking her talents to the prestigious Paris Conservatoire, she began shaping the minds of the next generation of musicians while probably insisting on complete attention at all times—no pressure, right?

events.event: Organizing music for Grace Kelly's wedding
events.summary: Boulanger had the honor of organizing the music for Prince Rainier of Monaco's wedding to Grace Kelly, a task she probably approached with more flair than many wedding planners would dare to!
Boulanger became an honorary member of the international women's music fraternity, perhaps thinking, 'Finally, a sisterhood that knows the importance of good music and good company!'
Boulanger received the ultimate invite—to the White House by JFK! One can only imagine the music-filled conversations that stirred up between the First Couple and the legendary composer.

Just shy of her 90th birthday, Boulanger was surprised with a birthday bash that had all the pomp of a royal celebration, complete with floating candles, proving one is never too old for a little fanfare.
In a dazzling ceremony, she received the Chevalier to the Légion d'honneur, marking her as a French musical treasure and making the local gossip mill spin about who wore the best beret.
Being recognized with the Order of Polonia Restituta felt like being handed the ultimate backstage pass to Poland's cultural revival—it's safe to say she was the star of the show.

events.event: Foreign Honorary Member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences
events.summary: Nadia became a Foreign Honorary Member, showing that even across the ocean she was like a secret agent of musical magic, known for her charm and uncanny ability to make notes dance.
Winning the Howland Memorial Prize was the cherry on top of her already sweet musical career, because who doesn't love a good trophy to put next to their piano?

events.event: Médaille d'Or of the Académie des Beaux-Arts
events.summary: Receiving the Médaille d'Or was like being crowned queen of the arts—no tiara required, just a whole lot of talent and a flair for the dramatic.

events.event: Grand officier to the Légion d'honneur
events.summary: Achieving the title of Grand officier to the Légion d'honneur was her way of saying, 'I’d like to thank my piano for the support, and my audience for their applause.'
Being honored with the Order of the British Empire made her the talk of the tea party, proving that music really is the universal language—especially when tea is involved.

events.event: Order of St. Charles of Monaco
events.summary: Nadia was bestowed the Order of St. Charles, making her not just a composer but also a royal favorite—after all, every royal needs someone who can compose a fit-for-a-prince anthem.

events.event: Order of the Crown of Belgium
events.summary: Scooping up the Order of the Crown was like getting a royal thumbs-up from Belgium itself; cheese sales probably went up after that!
